items.title: Please distribute tests in pypi archive
items.body:
We are using them to ship validate build in openSUSE and for now I had to switch to github tag tarball.

Simply adding the tests to MANIFEST.in is enough to get it rolling.

items.title: UnicodeDecodeError also happens on Python3
items.body:
Change line #60 in *unicodeutil.py* to:
`s = s.decode('utf-8', 'ignore')`
Same as in Python2 code just below.

Example:
Python 3.6.3 (default, Oct  3 2017, 21:45:48) 
**from easyprocess import EasyProcess**
**proc = EasyProcess(['whois', '-H', 'chp.edu']).call()**
`
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/shimi/cyberjack/crr/venv3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/easyprocess/__init__.py", line 194, in call
    self.start().wait(timeout=timeout)
  File "/home/shimi/cyberjack/crr/venv3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/easyprocess/__init__.py", line 268, in wait
    self._wait4process()
  File "/home/shimi/cyberjack/crr/venv3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/easyprocess/__init__.py", line 317, in _wait4process
    self.stdout = remove_ending_lf(unidecode(self.stdout))
  File "/home/shimi/cyberjack/crr/venv3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/easyprocess/unicodeutil.py", line 60, in unidecode
    s = s.decode()
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0x92 in position 116: invalid start byte
`

items.title: how can I view stdout/stderr while process is running?
items.body:
I see the note in the docs that stdout/stderr is only available after process is stopped.  Is there anyway around this?  I would like to periodically get stdout of a long running task.

Thanks.

items.title: Shlex split breaks windows paths
items.body:
When you set the cmd argument to a string, EasyProcess will call split_command to break out the cmd from its arguments.

On Windows environment, split_command will return invalid command.

For example:
`
split_command('c:\\temp\\a.exe someArg')
#returns ['c:tempa.exe', 'someArg']
`

The fix seems to be set the posix argument in shlex (see https://github.com/maebert/jrnl/issues/348)

https://github.com/ponty/EasyProcess/blob/master/easyprocess/unicodeutil.py#L44
`cmd = shlex.split(cmd, posix='win' not in sys.platform)
`

items.title: EasyProcess.__repr__() improvement
items.body:
firstly, thanks for a cool easy process helper

please change **init**.py line 118 from 
`msg = '<%s cmd_param=%s cmd=%s oserror=%s returncode=%s stdout="%s" stderr="%s" timeout=%s>' % (` to 
`msg = '<%s cmd_param=%s cmd=%s oserror=%s return_code=%s stdout="%s" stderr="%s" timeout_happened=%s>' % (`
("returncode" => "return_code", "timeout" => "timeout_happened")

that way, it's easier for people to guess the name of the return_code and timeout_happened variable.

also, "timeout_happened" isn't documented at all (no example, no mention of it) in readme.md

items.title: Any support for changing the operating system's environment variables while running a command?
items.body: subprocess allows passing along a env dictionary in the constructor.

items.body:

Program install error!

items.title: Doesn't report correct version to pip
items.body:
When I run `pip install EasyProcess`, it downloads EasyProcess-0.1.6 from PyPI, and installs it.  But then when I run `pip freeze`, it says `EasyProcess==0.0.0`.

Maybe it's fixed by the new version of Versioneer you just added, I didn't try.  Anyway, this really confuses Pip sometimes.

items.title: The system cannot find the file specified returncode=None on MS-Windows
items.body:
I downloaded ponty-EasyProcess-0633d2d from GitHub.

Installed as follows:

```
C:\Users\rwolf\Downloads\ponty-EasyProcess-0633d2d\ponty-EasyProcess-0633d2d>python setup.py install
some tasks could not not be imported.
running install
running build
running build_py
creating build
creating build\lib
creating build\lib\easyprocess

creating build\lib\easyprocess\examples
copying easyprocess\examples\hello.py -> build\lib\easyprocess\examples
copying easyprocess\examples\log.py -> build\lib\easyprocess\examples
copying easyprocess\examples\__init__.py -> build\lib\easyprocess\examples
running egg_info
creating EasyProcess.egg-info
writing requirements to EasyProcess.egg-info\requires.txt

warning: no files found matching 'CHANGES*'
no previously-included directories found matching 'docs\_build'
writing manifest file 'EasyProcess.egg-info\SOURCES.txt'
running install_lib
creating C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess
creating C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples
copying build\lib\easyprocess\examples\hello.py -> C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples
copying build\lib\easyprocess\examples\log.py -> C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples
copying build\lib\easyprocess\examples\__init__.py -> C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples
copying build\lib\easyprocess\__init__.py -> C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess
byte-compiling C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples\hello.py to hello.pyc
byte-compiling C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples\log.py to log.pyc
byte-compiling C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples\__init__.py to __init__.pyc
byte-compiling C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\__init__.py to __init__.pyc
running install_egg_info
Copying EasyProcess.egg-info to C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\EasyProcess-0.1.0-py2.7.egg-info
running install_scripts
```

Then attempted to run the example and got an error.

```
C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples>python hello.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "hello.py", line 4, in <module>
    print EasyProcess('echo hello').call().stdout
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\easyprocess\__init__.py", line 220, in call
    self.start().wait(timeout=timeout)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\easyprocess\__init__.py", line 255, in start
    raise EasyProcessError(self, 'start error')
easyprocess.EasyProcessError: start error <EasyProcess cmd_param=echo hello alias=None cmd=['echo', 'hello'] (echo hello
) oserror=[Error 2] The system cannot find the file specified returncode=None stdout="None" stderr="None" timeout=False>


C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\easyprocess\examples>echo hello
hello
```

I am running Python 2.7.1 on Windows 7 32 bit.

Any suggestions?

items.title: EasyProcess memory leak
items.body:
Code snippet:

``` python
        def shutdown():
            self._stop_thread = True
            self._thread.join()

        self._thread = threading.Thread(target=target)
        self._thread.daemon = 1
        self._thread.start()
        atexit.register(shutdown)

        return self
```

**atexit** calls it's registered handlers at program exit. 
But what if the main process that uses this is supposed to run forever, what if it's a server for example, than there is no such thing as program exit. In such case, every time the main process is starting the subprocess, the new reference to **shutdown** is stored  globally within **atexit**, causing a memory leak!

Was there a particular reason to not to call a **shutdown** from the class disposing method: **Proc._ _del_ _()** ?
